utterances: So from what we have been told and what local lore is that his father anglicized the spelling of the name because he liked William Makepeace Thackeray and that's why the name is spelled the way it was.
And so the traditional Indian pronunciation and spelling, you would probably come out with something like T-H-A-K-R-E, rather than Thackeray.
Well, Vikas Bajaj, thank you very much for talking with us about it.
Thank you.
Vikas Bajaj is the New York Times correspondent in Mumbai, a city which, by the way, was renamed Mumbai from Bombay, largely due to the efforts of Bal Thackeray.
Thackeray died this weekend at age 86.
Music video games are among the world's most popular, earning billions of dollars selling to gamers who delight in shredding through a song by Jimi Hendrix or Aerosmith.
NPR's Neda Ulaby says the company that makes Guitar Hero is tweaking that franchise with a new game that comes out tomorrow.
The game is called DJ Hero.
And it's about as true to actual DJ-ing as Guitar Hero is to actual rock stardom.
(Soundbite of music)
Jamie Jackson is creative director of FreeStyle Games, that developed both DJ and Guitar Hero.
It's not about you being a DJ and simulating.
That wasn't the idea.
It's about having fun and feeling like you're controlling the party.
So all the music is pre-made by our DJs.
Meaning it's a pre-mixed, pre-sampled, pre-beat matched assortment of popular tunes.
(Soundbite of music)
FreeStyle developers worked with about 20 DJs to figure out how to turn turntabling into something playable on an Xbox.
It works like Guitar Hero, but instead of that plastic guitar you get a fake turntable and a fake little mixer, while a funky DJ avatar struts, cuts and scratches onscreen.
He is enjoying himself.
Robert Carter is a DJ who plays nationally under the name DJ Cuzzin B.
By day you'll find him including audio for NPR's Web site.
I asked him to play DJ Hero.
It takes some getting used to, but then again, this is a game.
FreeStyle Games recruited a few illustrious DJs to add cred.
That's right.
It's a signature - this is at satellite altitude, so the situation was that we hadn't really had gravity data, not that much gravity, anyhow, for much of Antarctica.

And a few years ago, a mission from NASA, a GRACE mission - it's called Grace - and it's two satellites that have a radar ranging device that measures the distances between the two satellites, and that can be interpreted in terms of the gravity.
At any rate, the region is so harsh and difficult to get to that this satellite provided, you know, the best estimate of the gravity field of the area, frankly.
And on that scale, one could see the signature that you also saw on the moon and Mars.
Now, how do you date it?
How do you relate it to the great die-off that happened 250 million years ago?
Well, when you sort of plot out its structure, it has to be older than when Australia separated from Antarctica, and that happened at least 100 million years ago, and everything started even earlier.
So the coastline of Antarctica and Australia would cut through the rings on this thing, so this thing had to be older than that.

And also, since it has a signature at satellite altitude, it's relatively young because there's some other large features around the planet where you don't really see the effect at satellite altitude.
So I guess the way to put it is that it's like a swelling, you know, in the crust, and it goes away over time.
Just like when you bruise yourself, over time the swelling goes down.
Well, for the older craters, they've pretty much disappeared, but there's still some evidence of the signature of this at satellite altitude.
Mm-hmm.

So it's a very broad, you know, categorization of the time interval over which it could happen, but it had to be over 100 million years, and it's probably younger than say a half a billion years, say 500 million years.
And if you think, well, what sort of thing could this have triggered?
I mean, what sort of conditions were going on that might be - that this thing might be responsible for?
And the great extinction of 250 million years ago is one of these things, so that's sort of where we're coming from on it.
It must have wrung the planet a bit then and shook it up a bit.
Oh, yeah.
Yeah?
It - undoubtedly, this was bigger than the event that presumably caused the extinction of the dinosaurs, and it certainly messed up the environment.

I believe something like 90 percent of marine life went extinct at that point, and a lot of animal life on the surface of the earth, the terrestrial part of the planet, also was greatly, you know, went extinct.
So it was a big event.
Also, connected to it seems to be the Siberian Traps, which is on the other side of the planet, so this...
So tell us what that means.
This was a great lava plain that formed about 200 million years or 225 million years ago.
And often this is cited as being responsible for the - for this great die-off, and these things are connected, presumably, in time, may be connected - and certainly they are antipodal to each other.
So we see big impacts, say, on a place like Mars, where the great volcanic planes are actually antipodal to some of the large craters there, so we're looking into that.
I mean, this is what we're, you know, hypothesizing.
So if you punched it on one side of the planet in with a big crater, it bulges out on the other side as lava.
Right, that there might be an effect, you know, where you're firing up the lavas on the other side of the planet with it, and it...
Hmm, yeah.
So what else do you have to do sort of nail this idea down?
Is there anything else you can do?
Oh, yeah.
I think the most expedient thing to do is to fly over it with airplanes and collect gravity and magnetic fields with aircraft.
This region is very remote, and, of course, it's very harsh.
It's only been visited, as far as I can tell, maybe twice by flyovers back in 1957, '58, in the IPY, the International - the IPY...
The Physical.
...the International Physical Year...
Yeah.

I mean, we've been more times to the moon than humans have been to this area, and, you know, one could fly this and collect data at lower altitudes, at aircraft altitudes, to see if we see the types of signals that we see over something like Chicxulub, that was the event that presumably killed off the dinosaurs.
So do you have plans of doing this?
Well, we're - yes, we're trying to plan for it.
Let's say you could do that.
That would be the most expedient thing.

Another thing that could be done is to go along the coastline there and look at the rocks, because the great ice streams are coming across this thing and pushing out rocks, so they're gouging out the rocks, you know, over which the ice streams travel, and they're being pushed out as drift products that could be examined to see if they're meteorite fragments and shocked rocks and so forth in these things.
How deep do you think this crater is?
Well, I think it's very pervasive, so it's basically - it's raising up the mantle so, you know, the crust in this area's probably about 30 kilometers or so thick.
It's a little shallower than normal continental crust.
It's five to seven kilometers shallower, so you have - anyway, it's a very big event.
Yeah.
So it's pushing all the way through.
Thank you very much for taking time to talk with us.
Dr. Ralph Von Frese is professor of geological sciences at Ohio State University in Columbus.
The other day, The New York Times published a story.
It examined the way that Donald Trump's presidential campaign promoted his tax plan.
Trump had offered a big tax break to businesses.
His campaign told a leading business group that he supported the tax break, and he got their endorsement.
Then his campaign told independent budget analysts he was against the same tax break.
The point of this story for our purposes here is that the Times called this a lie - specifically, the trillion-dollar lie.
The Times is using that word lie quite often in its coverage of Donald Trump, so we've called Dean Baquet, who is the paper's editor, to talk about its coverage of the Republican candidate.
Welcome to the program.
Thank you so much.
Good to be here.
Has something changed in the way you cover and write about Donald Trump?
